  419. The Water Pik WP-360 is a great product concept and I enjoyed using it regularly, especially in the shower. Pressure (using the expert tip) is good while the unit is new and the batteries are fresh. Unfortunately after owning four of these over two years, I can say with authority this product is simply not built to withstand more than a few months of regular use regardless of how well it is cared for. If WP addressed the issues of poor battery characteristics and unacceptable reliability, this product would be a winner. Instead, I recommend the Panasonic EW1270AC Portable Oral Irrigator which is not rechargeable (uses AA batteries), has a smaller tank, and does not create as much pressure. However, it is well made and travels better since it is collapsible and does not need a charger. <br />

  422. This item stopped functioning within two weeks of its arrival at my home. The charger ran out after one or two uses, even the first few days, in spite of the fact that I charged it for 16 hours the first time, as advised in the instruction manual, and had to be recharged again over night. This item is made in China, home of (lately) massive product recalls all over the world. This item lacks product integrity, certainly won't improve China's current standing in the world of manufacturing, and, I think, the Waterpik company lacks integrity for selling this thing. Maybe their other products are good. This one isn't.

Better breath. - Much more enjoyable than flossing. - Cheap and portable. - Once you upgrade to a real waterpick system this will make a great squirtgun, you'll win every time in short battles ;-) OVERALL Wish I'd spent the extra $16 for a full powered, higher-end system, and will be ditching this for one soon.

  488. This product was not at all what I was expecting. First of all, it is so powerful that you practically have to use it in the shower to keep from drenching your entire bathroom.   489. Very, very noisy, and adding water to it in the standard bathroom sink is very difficult. A kitchen sink would work better, but who takes care of their dentition in the kitchen? For someone who is sold on using oral irrigation, it would make a good addition to your shave kit if you travel a lot. After about a month it just quit working altogether. I guess you shouldn't expect much for $21.

  495. I am about to throw out the third WP-360 that I have purchased. The first lasted a few months and I loved it. It cleaned between my teeth and took little space on the countertop. But then it died. So I gave in after a few months without and bought a second Waterpik cordless. It died after a much shorter period, a few weeks I believe. I gave up on irrigating between my teeth. But I really needed a dental irrigator; dental floss does not do the trick for me. I had gone months and months without and I could see how my teeth and gums were suffering. So I gave in, and bought another one. I thought this time would be different...........And this third one died much quicker. I found it hard to believe.   499. I cannot believe the poor design of the turning (360 degrees) head. Can you imagine the walls of the bathroom after you finished using it? OK, now please....fix the poor design before someone comes up with a law suit against the manufacturer for water suffocation. The poor design includes the three buttons (can the release one be moved somewhere else?). While trying to hold the head from turning, the ON and OFF buttons have to be under your finger before the water suffocation, then the head comes OUT. Well, I have ducted tape the head, so I can have one finger on the ON and another on the OFF buttons again before suffocation. Yes, you read it right, \\"DUCT Tape.\\" Lucky I that I had some white DUCT Tape in the house. I have no problem with the water tank size like others do. The health and hygiene of my gums are very important to me, and the waterpik does the job. The portable waterpik design could be better if the manufacturer wanted to. Reviews are available.
  500. I had mine for a couple of months and then I threw it in the trash. It was unwieldy, had minimal water pressure, and the jet tip wouldn't stay in place. It didn't add anything to my oral hygeine and it was taking up space on the counter. Waste of money.
  501. My dentist talked me into getting braces in my 40s, and I can't imagine surviving through orthodontics without a Waterpik -- there is no other way to do what these machines do. Having said that, Waterpik's quality control is dreadful. I have a personal model at home, and -- I am not making this up -- I had to send it back for replacement twice in the first week of operation. The woman in customer service actually said \\"Well, maybe the third time will be a charm\\", and in fact I have had no further trouble with that unit in three years. I own two WP-360W Waterpiks, one that I bought two years ago (and still going strong), and one that I bought on vacation last month. I used the new unit without incident for three weeks, and then it suddenly stopped operating. There was no transition period during which it worked intermittently or slowly; it abruptly stopped working, and as soon as I finish writing this review, I am going to throw it away. When it works, the WP-360W is a great product. Sure, it is noisy, and sometimes the tip pops off and spatters you with water because the designers located the \\"eject\\" button for the tip right next to the \\"on\\" button. But it does a good job, and it's a \\"must\\" if you wear braces and like to travel. I would strongly encourage you to keep your receipt for any Waterpik product you buy, because -- if my experience is typical -- you are likely to encounter quality problems. It's really a shame that their manufacturing QA mars what would otherwise be an excellent product.
  502. [[ASIN:B0002AHY6Q Waterpik WP-360W Hand-held Cordless Rechargeable Dental Water Jet]] This is the 3rd of these that I have owned. The first 2 lasted about 1 year each. The first stopped being able to be charged, the second because something became disconnected internally and it wouldn't pump any more. This device cost me less than $30, far less than the $102 I pay for teeth cleaning twice a year and far less than the jaw bone implant I had before I started using a waterpik. It fits my hand nicely and is easy to store in my small bathroom and I clean between my teeth and gum in one fill of the reservoir. I start by brushing my teeth, then flossing, then waterpik and finally use a mouth rinse to disinfect. I will definitely buy another when the current one stops working.
  503. I bought this shortly after I got braces. I chose this model because I don't have the counter space in my bathroom for the big tank and it was a reasonable price. I only use it once a day and worked great. I did notice that I had to fill up the tank 2 times sometimes 3 to get through one cleaning. I am ok with that, its not that annoying. However, after about 4 months of use it completely died and wouldn't charge. Since this model has a 2-year warrenty I contacted Waterpik and they sent me a brand new unit with in a week. They suggessted that you remove the pressure tip after each use because water that is left inside it can seeps back down inside and in the battery housing (it doesn't tell you that in the directions). I have done that since I got the new one and have had no issues. I don't have to charge it very often. I was very please with Waterpik for quickly taking care of the situation. I think others who are complaing about the battery losing charge and buying a new one should have taken advantage of the warranty information. Overall, I do notice a difference with the use of this water jet, it helps a lot with braces. Even though I did have charging problems too, I was very pleased with the quick response from Waterpik. I would recommend this to any one who doesn't want to spend a lot or doesn't have room for a large tank model.
  504. The waterpik is a great product - this is my second one. The first one is mine and the one I just bought is for my daughter. I have nothing bad to say - it works and it's great. Btw, the first one I bought has been in use for three years with no problem whatsoever.
  505. Portable and cheap this Waterpik has worked great I recommend it with my eyes closed! Just be careful and follow instructions!
  506. After only a few months of use it quit taking a charge. While shopping for a replacement, I happened to read some reviews and found that others had similar experiences and one reviewer had replaced the connectors between the unit and the charger. That gave me an idea. I simply cleaned the contact points, plugged it up, and after a few hours it is all charged up and working like new. I used one of those toothpicks with a fuzzy brush tip and some warm soapy water and was careful to dry it thoroughly before plugging it in to charge.
  507. DOESN'T HOLD A CHARGE for more than a year!!!! I am so disappointed in this product. At first, it was great. It has a lot of power and I could use it easily without having to recharge it so frequently. Now, it will not hold a charge for more than 5 seconds.AGHHHH!

  535. I purchased this unit for traveling (I also have a full-size WaterPik) and it works just as I expected it to. My problem is the colored reservoir--I add Listerine or hydrogen peroxide to the water supply and the blue color is impossible to see through, even when holding it up to the light. So, there's no way you could fill it only part way, then add the Listerine, because you can't see what \\"part way\\" is. So, I would fill it full (the only way I was able to tell when it was full is when it spills over the top), and pour a little out to make room for Listerine. However, because the reservoir holds so little, I would inevitably end up pouring out more than I intended, fill it up again, pour some water out again..oh, heck, it was just a hassle.<br /><br />If you only use water, this product works just fine.   546. I have had this item for nearly a year, but not quite long enough for the warranty to have yet expired. When I first received it I was quite impressed. Great power. I have read a lot of complaints about the small size of the reservoir, but I have to tell you, I did not have an issue with that. I was able to get all my squirting done in the prescribed time before running out of water. I mean how long should it take, it can only squirt so deep, unless you have teeth the size of Mr ED, I don't think it should be a problem. Sounds like to me there may be a lot of overkill squirting going on. Well enough of that, time to move on. My issue was the battery. In only a few months the battery died and I could not charge it. I was bummed, because I really loved this product and it did a great job. So I contacted Waterpik Customer Service and there was no hesitation, they sent me out another unit immediately. What a great bunch of folks there. The unit I received was not as good though. It had only about half the power of the first, which could be why everyone else was continually reloading the unit with a fresh dose of natures natural nectar. I used the replacement one for about 4-5 months and just the other day I sent customer service another email advising them of my unhappiness with the second unit. They have again immediately replied and offered an upgrade of a different unit. I have not yet decided what to do yet, but I have to tell you Waterpik Customer Service has been outstanding thus far. I guess I gave this item 2 stars because it just has not been dependable or efficient. This is a shame because in the past I had a big home plug in unit that could drill a water hole through a molar in 10 seconds. Not this unit though. I will let you know what happens on this.

  550. **The pump breaks down because small particles of food end up in the reservoir and it clogs the pump.**<br /><br />I've been using the WP-360W for a few days now and I love it. I'm not sure how I've been going without it. I recently got braces, so food is always stuck in the darn things. I like that the WP-360W is portable. I take it with me to work everyday and use it after each time I eat something. I just finished eating a bunch of peanut M&M's, so I went to wash my mouth out with the Waterpik. After I was done, I noticed chunks of peanut all over the top of the Waterpik. I remembered seeing chunks of food the previous times I used it this week, but this morning, it dawned on me as to why some people were saying their pump quit working after a while. The chunks of food were always almost going right into the reservoir as I was about to make another fill up. IMO, it would be best to fill up the 2nd time, but drain the water out before use, so that in case any chunks did fall inside, you'll be more than likely to get them out when you dump the water.<br /><br />I think the problem people are having with the charger is that they are getting the adapter recepticle wet. I noticed that the cover sometimes doesn't close over the hole, or that I didn't close it after taking the Waterpik off the charger. Of course anyone that use this device will know that water goes all over the place, so naturally, water most likely dripped inside the adapter hole.<br /><br />I think it's quite unfair to give this product a 1 star. IMO, this device is great and does an outstanding job for something that costs $21.99 (no tax and shipping charges, either). $29.99 from the drug store might be a little much, but $21.99 is just right. The point I'm trying to make is that this device didn't cost much and if it was to break down after several uses, then it would be money well spent! I'm quite sure there have been times that every person that bought this Waterpik had bought a pizza pie that cost more than this, however, that pizza was gone in an instant. This Waterpik, although totally different in comparison with a pizza, is still a product, and like I said, if a person used this product several times over before it quit working, then why give it such a low score? Things like this don't last forever.<br /><br />5 Star rating! Way to go Waterpik. I love this product.an this, however, that pizza was gone in an instant. This Waterpik, although totally different in comparison with a pizza, is still a product, and like I said, if a person used this product several times over before it quit working, then why give it such a low score? Things like this don't last forever. 5 Star rating! Way to go Waterpik. I love this product.

  552. My regular WaterPik was really good and recommended by my dentist. It lasted for about two years and then sprung a major leak. So I saw this version and thought, great! Less counter space and it's portable. Every time I use it, the nozzle pops out while I'm cleaning, which sprays water all over and requires me to stop, refit the nozzle and then continue--for another few seconds until it pops out again. By then, the chamber is empty and has to be refilled with water. The regular WaterPik holds enough water to last for two minutes. That's about the amount of time needed to do a thorough cleaning. This device runs out in about twenty to thirty seconds. And the dial at the base of the nozzle, which you're supposed to turn to direct the stream where you want it, tends to ensure that the nozzle pops out. This is almost useless. I'd like to find whoever designed it and send him or her for a check up with the dentist from Marathon Man.

  563. This device gives adequate irrigation with the more restricted tip. The more powerful tip is too strong and could pack food deeper in your gums [my dentist agrees]. Portability is it's best feature and vital if you travel much. The small resevoir requires 2-3 fillings to do what one can with the larger sink top model, and it's somewhat messier to use. For the price and portability, a good buy!

[[ASIN:B0002AHY6Q Waterpik WP-360W Hand-held Cordless Rechargeable Dental Water Jet]]
  617. I chose this model for its small counter footprint compared with the previous devices I have owned. It has the advantage of not using a flexible tube to connect the pump to the hand peice, which tends to collect mold, and is nearly impossible to clean. The water tank is small, but it is easily filled and refilled using a glass of lukewarm water, rather than directly from the tap, as it doesn't fit under my bathroom sink faucet. Battery charge has not been a problem, but I recommend recharging after every two or three uses, to insure long battery life. Operating the unit until the battery is fully discharged before recharging will cause early battery failure, and it is not replaceable. The size and battery power make it suitable for travel. Jet pressure is only adjustable by changing tips. This is satisfactory, but an adjustable pressure control would be a significant improvement.
  618. The Waterpik WP-360W is a great device! It doesn't take up a lot of room, that was a prerequisite for me. I charge it up once a week. The 30 seconds is enough for me. Hope my next visit with the hygienist shows improvement. Try it, you'll like it!

  622. I love my waterpik! I use it daily and it helps with removing food stuck between teeth & flossing. It's very strong. I have 3 different waterpik models, this being one of them. The nice part about this one is it's good for travel, holds an excellent charge! I charge mine only every 2 months typically.<br />The only reason I'm giving this 4 instead of 5 stars is that 2 days ago I found that mold grew inside the very bottom of the water reservoir - gross! The reservoir is very deep with only a very small opening at the top - making my job at cleaning it verrrrryy difficult. I put vinegar in it, then bleach and water mixture, I got a lot of the gunk out but then used a long disposable chopstick to scrape the bottom very clean, then did a thorough bleach & water mixture, followed by vinegar again and several water rinses. I wish a warning was included in the instructions so that I would look for mold sooner and do weekly cleans to prevent it, which I will now being doing. Plus it would be nice to have another opening to access the bottom to clean it well.<br />Also pull the blue reservoir away from the white motorized base and wipe it clean from time to time.<br />All in all - this tool is invaluable if you hate flossing and want to keep cavities from growing between your teeth. Definitely a worthwhile purchase !!!! I have recommended it to many family and friends which have purchased it with wonderful results.

  626. So here's the deal.<br />I've used Waterpik devices for 10 years, mainly the plug in AC models. Nothing beats them for capacity. WHEN it is charged freshly, and that means you get about 3 uses before it runs dead and needs a recharge, it is very effective. It is a little cumbersome to reach in the back while leaning over the sink at work with people watching you, but you get over it...<br /><br />Cons: The battery packs in all three died after 6-8 months. I took one back to Walmart (only two came from Amazon) and that got me through until the end of my braces...<br /><br />The truth: For the money, and unless you travel and need it on the road or wear braces and need to floss after meals at work, you are better off getting the A/C model, as my last one is 6 years old and still going strong. I spent roughly $140.00 on all three, and they are now recycling themselves in some landfill. A removable, replaceable battery pack would be a bonus.

  693. For $25 it is a good product. I'm going to give this product the benefit of the doubt. To the people that say it doesn't hold enough water, the package says that it holds 30 seconds worth of continuous spray. If this isn't enough it is easy to refill, or go with a larger model (more $$$ and counter space) Also, there are many complaints about the battery. I haven't had the product long enough to comment on the life of the battery but if you FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS there shouldn't be a problem. One reviewer said they let the battery die completely to avoid it developing a memory, and that is what you should do with most rechargeable batteries. BUT the directions specifically say NOT to let the battery drain all the way on this model. Overall it is a good oral irrigator for its low price, and size. If you are unsatisfied with it take advantage of the warranty :)

Sometimes the chamber can get yellow mildew or algae (we have it in out well water) so I have eliminated this problem by throwing a capful of mouthwash into it and letting it sit overnight. I also remove the pick portion nightly and prop the unit upside down to drain well. This process is working well for me. I liked this so much I got one for my son as well.

  754. The product works well, and ours actually lasted for several years. Only the battery failed on us.<br />* After 5 years, our drive gear shows very little wear, only the faintest hint of darkening of the silicone grease.<br />* The little power brick is rated 100ma, 3V, but I found it to be 3.7V. I didn't verify BEFORE it failed; however, it's a transformer, rectifier, and a filter cap. If something failed internally, I'd expect ripple to go up, or voltage to go down, or squealing from a transformer short. None of that seems to have happened.<br /><br />The way to keep the battery alive for so long is to NOT keep it plugged in. The \\"memory effect\\" of NiCd batteries can be at play; however, you can \\"recondition\\" them by using them down to where the motor stops, then immediately recharging it.<br /><br />Because it's a NiCd battery pack, you must NOT leave this on the charger. You want to charge it up for (overnight) and then leave it unplugged. Use it until it doesn't have the power to clean anymore, then recharge it.<br /><br />This isn't a smart device -- there is no trickle charge, nor battery conditioner. Overcharging a NiCd causes venting of hydrogen and oxygen from the breakdown of the water in its electrolyte. It's a one-way valve. Once the battery is dried out, that's it.<br /><br />Also, don't leave it \\"on\\" with the battery dead. Because this has 2 cells in series, one cell will always be slightly lower power than the other. Once it goes below 2V, the weaker of the 2 cells will reverse polarity. If it's left in this condition, the other cell will reverse-charge it, causing it to off-gas its electrolyte, killing that cell completely. If that happens, you can't recharge it, and trying will make the battery pack get hot.<br /><br />The battery is P/N 37059-7, the same as for the WP350. Amazon sells a replacement as [[ASIN:B000V2DN24 Battery for WaterPik 350W travel model.]] It's more than half the cost of this unit (makes sense once you open it up) and requires soldering. Probably not worth the cost.<br /><br />The battery is made of two 4/5 sub-C cells with solder tabs. It's just like a C cell, but 4/5 as long, and the + nub doesn't stick out as fer. It's NiCd 1000mAh at 2.4V. You can pick up two 2200mAh 4/5 Sub-C cells with solder tabs for about 1/5th the cost of the Waterpik unit. Once the 2 cells are connected, you can just wrap it in clear tape unless you happen to have heat-shrink tubing handy. Surgery is about 5 minutes.<br /><br />NOTE: You can't throw these away legally because of the amount of cadmium in the battery pack. It's toxic and leaches into the water supply. Don't be lazy. This needs to be taken to your local battery recycling shop. If you can pull the cells out, that's even nicer, but not really necessary. Most hardware stores and battery stores will take returns for recycling.<br /><br />The unit itself is fairly cheap, so if you treat it right and get 2-5 years out of it, then great. If you're prone to leaving things plugged in all the time, then you'll definitely feel cheated on this.orth the cost. The battery is made of two 4/5 sub-C cells with solder tabs. It's just like a C cell, but 4/5 as long, and the + nub doesn't stick out as fer. It's NiCd 1000mAh at 2.4V. You can pick up two 2200mAh 4/5 Sub-C cells with solder tabs for about 1/5th the cost of the Waterpik unit. Once the 2 cells are connected, you can just wrap it in clear tape unless you happen to have heat-shrink tubing handy. Surgery is about 5 minutes. NOTE: You can't throw these away legally because of the amount of cadmium in the battery pack. It's toxic and leaches into the water supply. Don't be lazy. This needs to be taken to your local battery recycling shop. If you can pull the cells out, that's even nicer, but not really necessary. Most hardware stores and battery stores will take returns for recycling. The unit itself is fairly cheap, so if you treat it right and get 2-5 years out of it, then great. If you're prone to leaving things plugged in all the time, then you'll definitely feel cheated on this.

  776. This model of Waterpik is very &#34;user friendly&#34; as it can be used in the shower. I've gotten better dental exam results since I began using one. My hygienist tells me to &#34;Keep doing what you're doing&#34; since I started using one.<br /><br />Nevertheless, it has some significant problems. The previous model had a standard recharging socket that was prone to corrosion, thus limiting the lifetime of the unit, as once corroded, it would no longer take a charge. Many of the complaints that I've viewed for the current model, were actually commenting on the previous model. The redesigned charger socket is much less prone to corrosion, and can be easily cleaned.<br /><br />Yet I still have had problems with the current model. The charging &#34;brick&#34; failed after a year. This is highly unusual, and I doubt if it will happen to other owners. Another issue is the rechargeable battery, itself. I only got a couple of year's use out of it. From reading other reviews, it does look like it is still a problem with this model, yet no one has offered an easy solution.<br /><br />Rather than buying an entire new unit, I simply took it to Batteries Plus, and had them replace the original batteries with new ones. This will run about $15, so it is much cheaper than replacing the entire WaterPik.

  784. I bought this water flosser to replace an older one that the battery had worn out on. That one worked for 4 years without incident. I just plug it in overnight every weekend. The water reservoir holds just enough to do your mouth once. If you need more water it is easy to refill. I turn it off and start at a differant spots when my mouth fills up with water. Whatever works for you is good. So far the battery issue on the other reviews is'nt a problem yet, sence I haven't had it very long. I hope the warrenty will take care of that if the time comes.   818. Ok, I am now using my third portable waterpik. I think the reason for the battery problem is where they put the charging socket, on the front of the unit where water can often enter. The rubber socket cover is not adequate to keep water out. Nevertheless, I travel often and use my waterpik after every possible meal, and swear using them has saved me thousands in potential dental bills. I used to use the plug in kind and they are hands down 100 times better, but if you can't use an ac model, then this is the way to go. They do have a two year warranty. I think I will send two of them back together and I'll let you know whether the warranty is honored. Either way I'll continue using one and just consider it a disposable item. Easy annual gift from one of my kids! Also, if your kids have braces a Waterpik is a must!
  819. It's neither as easy to use or efficient as the regular model, but it takes up less counter space and does a fairly good job of dislodging food hiding between teeth. However, mine was sent from factory missing one tip, and the company has yet (several weeks have passed since being notified) contacted me or sent me the second tip. Each tip allows a different amount of water pressure to be applied to gums.
  820. I loved this Waterpik at first because I'm limited on counter space and it seemed the perfect solution. However, after about 8 months of using it I wish I would've bought the plug-in version. Just like many other reviewers I find that the thing will not hold a charge for very long. You might not think it's a big deal to recharge it but a full charge delivers the full amount of pressure and the correct jet pressure delivers the results you're after. My dentist just told me that my gums don't look as good as they did 3 months ago because my Waterpik is ineffective unless fully charged. Sooooo.... I will be researching a better quality unit and would caution anyone who's thinking of purchasing this.

  907. I have owned the Waterpick 360 for about a year now (actually bought it from Target cause I had a great coupon). Reservoir is absolutely adequate for whole mouth, I didn't want something that was to heavy. As a woman, fits in my hand just fine, I wear a medium size glove. I charge it up before travel for 2 week trip and leave the plug at home. Just wish there were some grip lines on the handle. So, I am very happy with the unit and got rid of the water pick that sat on my counter top. This is much cleaner. No water all over the counter. I clean it by running a little white vinegar through it, keep the lid open and set it upside down to drain well. I would recommend this product.

  930. I bought a WaterFlosser--which was real' stupid--because I already have a showerhead that can perform its oral hygienic irrigation function much more effectively. I've never sacrificed a loyal $20 on such a lost cause (That's saying a lot! Many years ago, I paid that amount for \\"The Reagan Diaries\\". If I wanted to read the rambling, childishly patriotic musings of an aging conservative who makes frequent spelling errors, I should've become penpals with someone at the nursing home). To be fair, I should add that the Flosser's reservoir can be loaded with mouthwash. It sounds like a great feature, but that was just way too much Listerine, way too pressurized, way too quickly. The silver lining to that dental trauma was that the intense, minty burning sensation gave me some much-needed empathy for fire eaters--but I'm still comfortable with thinking of them as subhuman.<br /><br />But seriously...my first one wouldn't charge and WaterPik sent me a replacement; it was completely free! This was a gesture that I very much appreciated. The customer service person was extremely polite, didn't ask a ton of questions, didn't require a receipt--I only needed the unit number, which was labeled on the product itself. However, the (fully functional) replacement wasn't worth the money that I sacrificed for it. As I mentioned above, I already own a showerhead. On a related note, WaterPik manufactures showerheads. They probably came up with this admittedly clever idea to squeeze some extra money out of the consumer class. Maybe the bigger one is a better product, it has a four-point-something star rating. I would recommend that you try it, but it would be reckless to take the advice of an internet stranger who writes really long product reviews.

  1012. Works great - Size is perfect for travel.
  1013. It okay, it does the job and is a nice size to sit on counter top. Easy to clean. Has 2 heads one is a pulse the other is soft. Seems to hold a charge for a good ant of time.
  1014. I'm old enough to be on Social Security & have never, never, before written a negative review about anything.<br /><br />This is the second unit I bought where the battery / charger / switch system deteriorated in about 16 months. The unit contains a flexible, bi-shape (one shape on -- one shape off), stamped metal switch that seems to either wear or loose its precise bi-shape memory. The result is that either the switch does not make sufficient contact to deliver sufficient power to the motor, or it always maintains a slight contact that drains & ages the battery. Manually reshaping this \\"switch\\" restores proper function for a short time. But, such cold reshaping further deteriorates the metal's shape memory and the same type of failure follows sooner & sooner as additional fixes are applied.
  1015. I have braces and the Waterpik seems to be the only practical way to keep them clean. I'm also a road warrior, flying weekly, so the cordless is the only model that's feasible. On both of those accounts this product would get a 5-star rating. My dentist and orthodontist both rave about my hygiene and they fit perfectly in my small carry on.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I've not had one last more than 3 months. I get no warning they're failing, they just die. They won't charge and I've never post-mortem'ed one to see what failed. While it's true they're waranteed for a year, I found the warantee process more cumbersome than just buying a new one every three months. At $26 they're cheap enough that it's not worth waiting more than two days for replacement. Their pathetic lifespan is the reason for the 2 star rating.<br /><br />Until the braces come off I'll keep using, and trashing them. It's worth $8 per month to keep things this clean. As soon as I'm unwired though, I'm through with this product and I'll return to flossing.
  1016. I purchased the Waterpik WP-360W in September 2011 and within 6 months began having problems with it holding a charge.   1029. Very poor design - I regret buying it without looking up reviews.<br />1. Reservoir capacity too small/cap difficult to pry open with arthritic fingers. Multiple fillings necessary.<br />2. Charge lasts two flossings; second one noticeable weaker.<br />3. One set of tips. That means $10 more to buy additional ones. Tip hard to maneuver. Need 2 hands: 1 to hold, 1 to rotate tip. Oops---out of water!<br />4. Water stream pressure only adjustable only by changing tips.<br />5. Recharger is plug-in and terminals not protected<br />6. Should be recharged with inductive non contact/sealed base like my cordless Braun Sonic tooth brush.<br />7. I have just used it 4 times. When the battery dies (as others indicate will be soon) I will use the unit for target practice. Varmint!
  1030. This is my third Waterpik. I use it daily usually after brushing my teeth. It does a great job of cleaning teeth and gums. What wears it<br />down after a couple of years are mineral deposits from the water. I haven't found a way to clean this but replacing the Waterpik is not<br />costly.
  1031. Yes, my Dentist recommended it and uses one himself. The high pressure nozzle is high pressure, be careful. I would NOT recommend a child use it because of the possiblity for accidents. Adults need to be aware of where it is pointing before turning it on. I find it easier to use in the shower as I don't have to worry about the spray/splash getting all over the mirror and vanity. It does a good job. The reservoir empties pretty quickly. I prefer the low pressure tip.
  1032. This is a terrible product. It has very little cleaning force and holds a very small amount of water. You have to fill it several times to get a complete cleaning.   1033. My dentist suggested I buy a Waterpik so I did. This one is so simple to use and I can really feel it getting between my teeth and a little under my gums. Waterpik has a warranty on their products, but when I went to the website, I needed information I didn't have on me... and time just kept passing and I eventually just bought a new one. There is a button to eject the applicator, and two other buttons to turn on and off. Sometimes, my finger will slip and not hit the off button when I think its going to and I end up squirting water everywhere. Not really a fan...
  1037. Easy to use. Small enough not to be an eyesore on the bathroom sink. Also portable to be used in the shower. Has enough power to clean gums well. I charge it once a week and use it about once a day. I would have given it 5 stars, except for two negatives: I don't like the fact that the battery is not replaceable, and have read other reviews about how after a year or so of use, you have to throw it out. I don't like disposable, and would have preferred to pay a couple of more bucks and have a battery I could replace. Also, you have about 30 seconds to do your whole mouth before the water well empties, so unless you want to take the time to refill mid mouth, you have to move pretty quick around your gums. I bought three more of these for my adult kids, and they're all really happy with them.
  1038. This was a replacement for another Waterpik which after several years of service would no longer work. I liked the first I had and so far this works well. It does a good job of cleaning between teeth.
  1039. It works better than I expected! It got here on time and preforms well. Have only had to charge it once so far.
  1040. I did not buy this product from Amazon, for I found it at a somewhat lower price at a local store. But I wanted to write a review anyway.<br />I have used this flosser for about a month, and it is very adequate though not quite up to expectations. The main problem is that it has to be recharged more often than the advertising implies. I use it twice a day and need to recharge it about every third day. It does not run down completely before I recharge it, but when it slows down I plug it in again, overnight. Another problem, as several reviewers have said, is that the reservoir does not hold enough water for a thorough cleaning. I usually fill it twice. But THIS IS NOT BAD. I would rather do this than try to handle a larger, more awkward machine. So far as cleaning is concerned, I think it does a very good job. I have just used the less powerful jet, but the first time I used it I got more stuff out than I with a previous flossing. Ever since then I have used the waterpik before flossing, and have not found any residue when I later flossed. One strange but inconsequential thing is that even though I fill the reservoir with warm water, the first water to come out when you turn it on is cool. I would like to know why.
  1041. Our previous water pick/flosser worked beautifully for at least 10 years; due to a domestic accident it got ruined. We bought a WP 360w from a local retailer as a replacement. What a dud. You have to charge the battery for 24 hours, unlike my rechargeable toothbrush, there no little light to tell you that the unit is charging or when it is fully charged, or when it needs to be recharged. After 24 hours charging, I plugged it in and tried it. The motor running at full tilt is pathetically weak and the water stream barely perceptible compared to our old, plug in model. Unlike the old plug in model, you cannot adjust the strength of the water flow. Moreover, the water tank only holds about 4 oz. so you have to stop and refill it several times. We took this dud back to the retailer. What a piece of junk. Surprised that a company like Waterpik which wants to keep its reputation would keep this on the market. Are you listening, Water Pik? Take this piece of junk off the market. Bet you have a warehouse full of returned units!!
  1042. This product worked well for about 2 weeks. They sent me another one that lasted about 1.5 years. When this one quit I sent it to the factory for repairs. Optimistic perhaps. Water Pik sent it back immediately telling me it was no longer under warranty. I knew that, but expect things to last a little longer or at least be repairable. They further explained that they don't service any of their products. On principle I'm disappointed that they expect you to just toss this item after its short life.<br /><br />I'm a recycler so I got out my screwdrivers, pry tools, and pliers to break it down into plastics and metal. This took about 20 minutes and specialty screwdrivers - tiny ones a watchmaker might use. Of further concern is that buried inside (inaccessible and unknown to consumers) is a fancy battery with a notice that says clearly \\"do not dispose in municipal trash\\" - or something to that effect. Don't remember if there was any warning about this in the product manual, but even if there were, who are they kidding?<br /><br />Worth it for the dental value, but consumers should look into other options. I encourage Water Pik to work on these end game issues.
  1043. This is my second. Yes, the battery isn't replaceable so when it stops charging you have to buy another. But the price is modest and the item is excellent. It cleans my teeth really, really well. The first probably saved me its price in floss, because I used to use a yard of floss, and after first cleaning my teeth with the waterpik, a small bit of floss is plenty and the floss always comes out clean anyway. But the real cost savings is, of course, dentistry. This is just an excellent, convenient, efficient, moderately priced product. I wouldn't be without one now. I wish I'd replaced the first sooner, because the battery was poor for a while, and I had to recharge it every day. Now, I've charged it once and it's lasted over a week. Brilliant product.

  1052. I've read many reviews of this product while searching for an answer about a broken tip. Some have issues /w it but for the price I think you can't go wrong. I bought it last summer for my daughter who has some dexterity problems so cannot use regular floss. It is very convenient for her & allows her to keep her gums healthy & I might mention we have tried just about every method of flossing on the market. Last night it fell on the hard wood floor & the tip that was in it broke even with the insertion point so when I couldn't find an answer regarding ejection of the tip, but had however found someone who responded regarding the warranty & how easy it had been for them to have the company replace theirs so I decided to call the company. My experience /w them could not have been better they were polite, easy to understand my problem & walked me through the VERY easy fix. Fortunately I did have the &#34;hex screw driver&#34; required after that it was easy. I had already posted that question here so was going to answer it for others in my predicament but the system wouldn't allow me to answer my own question so here are the instructions I received: insert the hex screw driver into the broken off portion until it's tight then THERE IS a release button just above the on/off button which another reviewer had made reference to but apparently it only works if you have something longer in the tip area like another tip or in my case the screw driver, anyway after I had the screw driver in place all I had to do was push the eject button! To those who say the battery doesn't hold a charge, we are fortunate enough to have an outlet near my daughter's vanity/sink & we leave it plugged in unless she's using it. Actually, I thought that was what the instructions indicated you should do however having lost those I cannot say for certain just that it works for us.
  1053. THE WATERPICK QUIT WORKING AFTER 3 MONTHS. I CONTACTED WATERPICK AND AND THEY SAID THAT THE ITEM WAS ALREADY OUT OF DATE (ACCORDING TO THE SERIAL NUMBER). WATER PICK SAID THAT THEY WOULD REPLACE THE ITEM

  1067. My original waterpik broke and I replaced it with this one since it's a little smaller and easier to handle and hold. It is perfect and I love it even more than the original waterpik flosser!! Highly recommend this!!
  1068. The unit worked fine for about 15 months. Then it began being unreliable by not starting or pumping slower than it should. My problem turned out to be the switch. It had become corroded with green \\"rust\\", copper oxide. By removing the flexible metal switch component by removing two small screws, I was able to use a fingernail file to remove the corrosion both on the copper strip and the contact on the flexible metal strip. Now it works like new. Probably what happened over the months of multiple daily uses, water leaked in to the unit at the base of the tip. I never remove the tip except for occasional cleaning. The unit came apart with some difficulty after removing the two screws in the base. When I took the unit apart the inside had a lot of brown \\"slime\\", which was easily rinsed off with the help of a retired toothbrush. By the way, thinking that the battery might be the problem, I Googled the number on the side of the battery and ended up at batteryspace.com where there was a battery for $9.95 that looked like it would work. It is marketed for electric razors. But I did not need it, at least not yet.
  1069. Recommended by my dentist so I bought it through Amazon. Less expensive than if I had the dentist order it! Great product. Really makes your mouth feel clean
  1070. No problems, everything was as expected. Thank you.

  1078. I purchased this to replace a manual irrigation syringe after tooth extraction. The blue pik is for low pressure and the clear pik is for high. However, there really isn't all that much a noticeable difference between the two pressures. Either pik I used, both were too powerful for my gums and caused them to bleed. That's my fault, my dissolvable stitches are only 6 days old and my dentist specifically told me to avoid trauma to my gums and sockets. I probably would have been better off with the larger unit which has more discriminating levels of water pressure, but I'm on the road a lot for work so the portability factor won me over. I think this unit would be perfect for someone who has a healthy mouth, but I wouldn't recommend this for someone who still is recovering from dental surgery... too much water pressure. Mix in a capful of mouthwash into the reservoir (I use the kind with hydrogen peroxide for the whitening effect) and you save yourself one less hygiene task. It takes about two tanks to do a thorough cleaning, which is perfect because I use warm tap water for the first pass and a mix of tap and mouthwash for the second.

The first month the charge would last about a week, and progressively it was shorter and shorter, and after 4 months it would last 2 days (which means the 2nd day the flow is weak). Now it's been 4 and 1/2 months and I had to throw it away: a full night charge doesn't even last for 1 cleaning session, i.e. 45 seconds! That is really a scandal, now that batteries are very efficient. The battery in my electric toothbrush is more than 1 year old and each charging lasts 2 months (and I have been cleaning my teeth more than twice a day because of my braces).<br />I didn't buy it at Amazon but I wanted to give this feedback.

  1098. Too heavy and it doesn't hold enough water
  1099. First of all the tip keeps flying off. So, since I have to fix almost everything that I don't have to invent myself I drilled a small hole into the part that holds the tip in and put a small screw in it to hold it in. Second of all, the water jet is way too powerful and causes bleeding gums and pain. So, to fix and invent away this problem myself, since I always wanted to be an expert in all the products I pay other people for, I cut the cotton ends off a plastic Q-tip and jammed it into the tip as a flow restrictor and this makes the thing actually usable. The shape of the thing and the cap makes it really difficult to fill the reservoir from our fairly standard sink, and you have to fill it at least once during a &#34;flossing.&#34; If you can't fix and invent solutions like this YMMV and it may be completely useless to you.

  1101. As has been the experience of other reviewers, I have gone through three of the Waterpik WP-360s now. In each case, the unit fails to charge after some time. The first one failed in a few months after purchase and Waterpik sent me a new unit. This one failed just outside the warranty period. The third one was a gift from my brother, so I did not have a receipt, and I did not open it immediately. Once, I did, it worked on the first trip, but after sitting there for a month and a half it would not charge and does not work.<br />Contacted waterpik and they ask for the receipt (dont have) and they indicate that based on the serial number this is out of warranty. They graciously offered me a $10 coupon to buy a new one.<br />However, given the experience I am unlikely to get another one.<br />The small reservoir volume is also a deterrent as noted by others, as is the inability to get a decent pressure from it, even with the high pressure nozzle.<br />I have had a plug in kind of waterpik for about 6 years and it has worked reasonably well -- the hose connecting the tank to the nozzle started leaking and had to be replaced. Lately it seems to be making noise and may be about to die, but given that it has lasted so long, I am satisfied with that product.
  1102. I like aterpik products but this is so poorly designed I am throwing it away. First of all, you can't fill the water reservoir in a normal bathroom sink.   1114. I have had a Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser, which was great, until it started leaking everywhere after a year's use. Then, I got a new flosser through Amazon from ToiletTree Products, which only lasted two weeks before it stopped working. Now, I have the Waterpik Cordless model, and am underwhelmed. The pressure is too low, so it doesnt do the job it's supposed to, the reservoir is too small, so I have to fill it twice for one clean (and I dont dilly daddle around). The model is also bulky and difficult to hold properly. I wish I could take this one back!
  1115. This water-pik is terrible. <br /><br />I had to refill it FOUR times just to QUICKLY cover all 4 quadrants of my mouth.  SMALL reservoir!  If you want to do a thorough job, you're going to be refilling it all morning!<br /><br />The filling orifice is so small that you will overrun it unless you turn the tap down to a minimum.<br /><br />It's taller than the height of my faucet.  I have to tilt it awkwardly just to get the opening under my faucet.  Your faucet may be taller and not a problem.<br /><br />There's no adjustment on the pressure.  <br /><br />If you tilt it while using it, the water stops.  You have to keep the darned thing straight up in order to use it, meaning that you are drooling all over it and your hand.<br /><br />The socket for the charger is on the handle, meaning that when you're washing it off after you've drooled all over it, you're getting water in the socket.  To be safe, I'm waiting till the water in the socket dries before I plug it in to recharge.<br /><br />When you're using it, you're holding the entire device, not just a spigot.  It feels too clunky in my hand.<br /><br />I wish I'd bought it in a store so it would be easy to return.<br /><br />I'm going to use it only until I buy a better model.  Then it's going to be relegated to my suitcase just so I'll have _something_ for when I travel.<br /><br />DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY...

It's good for a once in a while travel use but not for regular use. I suppose you should get the bigger version of it for long use. You don't get much time out of te travel size.   1150. I really don't get the negative reviews of this product. I really love mine and wouldn't be without it. In fact after reading the negative reviews here I bought TWO MORE of them because I was afraid that the company might feel discouraged and pull them from the market. You are not supposed to leave it plugged into the charger at all times like many here are doing. You are supposed to let it run down and then charge it back up instead. You'll get a longer life out of the batteries that way. I've had mine for about three years now and it still works.<br /><br />Some say that it's an awkward design. I don't agree at all. It's very slim and ergonomic. I love the way it works, looks and feels. So what if it has a small reservoir. This is a PORTABLE unit. Simply refill it. It takes only seconds to do so. There's another model that has a reservoir that is about twice as big and yeah, THAT one is awkward. I find that just one filling of the reservoir is plenty though once you get the hang of it. Every once in a while I'll fill the reservoir with 3% Hydrogen Peroxide Solution and floss with that instead of just plain water so as to kill any bacteria between my teeth and around my gums. It says right on the label that you can gargle with it so why not? You can dilute it with 50% water if you want to be cautious. I'm very pleased with this Water Flosser.
  1151. Lets see, 30 seconds flossing, or 3 minutes spilling water, spraying the bathroom walls, and multiple refills for a unit that is so cumbersome it hardly fits in my sink?<br /><br />And why does the on switch work that way? Press it on, and when you release, it should turn off. The first time I turned it on it locks on and I'm getting sprayed with water while I turn it off. Who designs something like that? Did the designers even use it? Once I tried to press the button to release the tip, and I turned it on and sprayed the ceiling.<br /><br />This thing will sit in my closet until the day I get a bridge of crown that requires it, till then, I can floss 4 times in the amount of time it takes to use this thing once.

  1154. My dentist recommended the Waterpik, saying that, over the long term, it would improve the health of my gums. This product offers one of the least \\"friendly\\" user experiences you could imagine:<br /><br />- Terrible ergonomics - hard to hold (especially when wet) because of the slick plastic surface and a design that doesn't fit in the hand<br /><br />- No indicator lights - no way to know if the thing is charged, charging (when plugged in), or even working (unless water is squirting out, which mine stopped doing about 370 days into its lifespan)<br /><br />- Antique battery technology - remember back in the 1990s when you had to drain your cell phone battery all the way before recharging it? Well, welcome back to 1995, because this product uses the same battery technology, but without any user feedback on battery status<br /><br />- The battery holds a decent charge for about 2-3 days and then declines rapidly for another 3-4 days, which means that (1) you can't recharge it until it's fully drained BUT (2) the product doesn't operate under full power after the third day. Ridiculous.<br /><br />I suspect that the Philips Sonicare Airfloss is a vastly superior product and will check it out - but no more Waterpiks in this household.

  1222. My dental hygentist recommened this for my back teeth bc flossing every day wasn't doing it for me. I've added it to my routine and seems to be going well. Hard to get the hand of the water going everywhere and running down your chin and arm but if it keeps my gums healthy I'll take it.
  1223. This product works quite well, but only for a short period. After that, the unit will no longer charge, and it basically dies. I am about to dispose of my 3rd unit. The first two lasted about a year, which is marginally acceptable at this price. But the 3rd one stopped working after about 3 months. The result is not only an unreliable product, but also the annoyance of wondering at each use whether it will still work properly.. Definitely not recommended.
  1224. Reservoir is too small; it needs to be refilled twice for an adult mouth. This unit is too long for our bathroom sink; we have to refill it in the bathtub. Very bad design.
  1225. It's compact, powerful and efficient. Ultra portable. The water dispenser isn't very large but it's enough. Water power pressure is astonishing.
  1226. Takes a little to adjust but I like it. My dentist recommends to still floss traitionally but this is a great tool to use in the morning. Easily allows me to floss after every meal nested of just before bed

  1229. I have owned four regular Waterpik flossers all of which suffered, eventually, broken or cracked tubing near the waterpik jet handle...That's one HUGE NEGATIVE on the regular flossers. On the TRAVELER, it is GENTLER than the regular AND WILL NOT ALLOW YOU TO DAMAGE YOUR GUMS as I have probably mine with TOO MUCH PRESSURE FROM THE REGULAR FLOSSERS. Plus there is no cheap plastic tube to crack AND THEY ALL WILL.<br />Of course, this one holds less water but it can be used while connected to the charger so no need to disconnect. IT<br />IS SMALLER IN FOOTPRINT ON YOUR SINK OR COUNTERTOP; who needs more clutter?<br />In short THIS UNIT IS SAFER...DO NOT ALLOW YOUR KIDS TO USE THE REGULAR FLOSSERS! THEY CAN DO SERIOUS DAMAGE TO YOUNG GUMS...I have used these for almost 10 years and would suffer gingivitis without daily after meal use. I am LAZY on regular string flossing...no excuses...
  1230. Bought this Waterpik cordless flosser to supplement the home counter Waterpik. This one is used exclusively for travel and vacation.
  1231. As several other reviewers have noted, the WP-360W works well but has an inherently bad charging system. Not sure where the problem is, but after just 10 days of use, the unit stopped taking more than a minimal charge---enough to weakly spray water for a few seconds.<br /><br />It may be a mistake, but I've ordered the higher-end WP product and hope that it does not have the same issue.<br /><br />Buyer beware!
  1232. My dental assistant recommended the waterpik. I only require the basic waterpik, no extras. It works fine for what I need...and 'the price is right'!!!
  1233. I am a regular user of a countertop Waterpik, Model WP-60W. I use the Cordless Model WP-360W only when traveling, because of its greater portability.<br /><br />The WP-60W has adequate water pressure, not nearly as much as the countertop model, but it is a pulsating pressure, which I find important.<br /><br />The water tank on the WP-60W is small, and requires 2 - 3 refills during a session. The rechargeable battery on my unit permitted approximately 10 refills before needing recharging. Although the tip rotates, the entire unit must be manipulated to achieve the desired angle against ones teeth. Occasionally, food particles would find their way to the refill cap and care needed to be taken to rinse them away to prevent their entry into the tank.<br /><br />During my first use of the unit, the motor and pumping action stopped completely. Close investigation revealed a small speck of dirt clogging the tip, which was cleared using a small wire.<br /><br />Previous models of this product were subject to corrosion of the recharging terminals at the base of the unit. While the terminals are still at the base, they are more visible, allowing for easier observation, prevention, and clearing of possible corrosion.
  1234. It does what we wanted it to.It stulates our gums. Easy to operate.a little hard to use.Sometime it squirts all over.<br />You have to learn to handle it.
  1235. After it starts sputtering, I think it's empty but there is still a lot of water left when I dump it. Which is weird. Although, I do think that one tank full of water is enough. It is kinda bulky, not awful though. I wouldn't mind a more ergonomic design. But my gums are looking good!
  1236. I love the way it works. It is very easy to pack to go places. It is so compact and I love it.
  1237. We've been using this for almost a year now and the DDS has told me that 'whatever you're doing, keep doing it! Your gums are looking great!' Would recommend this product to anyone and everyone for daily dental hygiene. Love it!

  1240. I was completely satisfied with the product. It was delivered in a timely manner, met all of the criteria I expected and I'm sure it'll be enjoying it for a long time.
  1241. i have one of the waterpiks that attach to the shower head through a thin tube, and always thought what a waste of water to run the thing with the shower open - using like 2 gallons of water to do one cleaning. so i bought this mainly because it uses less water. it takes time to get use to the pulsing jet, but it works well and all in all i am satisfied. refilling the reservoir every time is a small price to pay for saving water!
